description:
Rack ‘em up!
Join us every week at the Residence Bar for our Weekly Pool Competition, where skill meets excitement! Whether you’re a seasoned pro or just looking for some friendly competition, this is your chance to show off your moves and compete for bragging rights and great prizes
. Grab a drink, bring your A-game, and enjoy the ultimate pool night vibes
. Don’t miss out—cue up and let’s play!

Interislander is docking onshore to bring burger lovers something truly special — The Love Ferry a spicy beef and pork patty with melted Kāpiti brie, caramelised onions, roasted red peppers, rocket, truffle aioli, crispy Harringtons bacon and pickled jalapeños in a Poneke Bakery red brioche bun, with smoked paprika and sea salt sprinkled fries.
This gourmet tribute to the love of food is served straight from the iconic Interislander ship box. Back by popular demand, the Interislander pop-up burger truck is making waves once again, offering a taste of the Interislander experience without even setting sail.

This August, Beach Babylon becomes Club Tropicana, a retro, romantic escape inspired by 1960s tropical honeymoons, classic tiki bars and vintage beach glamour. Picture golden sunsets, flamingos, thatched umbrellas and the carefree buzz of a sun-soaked getaway, right in the heart of Wellington. No passport required.

The menu is vibrant and full of escapist flair. Start with coconut prawns and banana blossom kokoda, then dive into mains like mango glazed  pork rib rack or the tropical tofu paneer curry. Save room for dessert: pineapple upside-down pudding or a coconut rum fondue to bring the tropical fantasy to a sweet finale. Behind the bar, the tiki and kava-spiked cocktails flow freely, from Blue Hawaiian’s to retro rum punches, all dressed to impress with flamingo stirrers, umbrellas and tropical garnishes.

A golden-age soundtrack sets the mood, featuring the smooth calypso of Harry Belafonte, beachy vibes from The Beach Boys, and sun-drenched classics by Astrud Gilberto.

Club Tropicana is a winter getaway, fun and fabulously over the top.

A huge exhibition of national artists will be on display at Tākina in August.
Artists from every corner of New Zealand will be vying for a $25,000 grand prize.
The Wellington Sculpture Trust will mount a display celebrating 42 years creating and promoting public art in the city.
Finally, nine South Island artists sharing Netherlands heritage exhibit an irreverent show through a multicultural creative lens.
NZAFA President Wayne Newman says “Tākina is Wellington’s new heart of creativity, and we’re delighted to fill it with the vision, energy, and diversity of New Zealand art.

Are you the maths lead in your school?
Register to join our Mathematics Leadership Community (MLC) and build your mathematics and statistics knowledge and leadership skills.
These MLC’s have been supporting mathematics leaders and teachers for over 18 years and we are excited to offer you the opportunity to be part of this network in 2025, which is shaping up to be a pivotal year in mathematics education.
Through engaging with current research and best practice, these meetings will enable leaders and teachers to: stay up to date with changes and implement Te Mātaiaho, Mathematics and Statistics Curriculum build capability in leading mathematics and statistics within and across their school investigate effective pedagogy and strategies for teaching and assessing mathematics and statistics connect and network with other leaders and teachers.
$350 for a 2025 Membership (+gst and booking fees) $100 for 1 meeting (+gst and booking fees) *Each ticket purchased gives entry for two attendees from 1 school* For any Kāhui Ako interested in this series, please contact us at info@cognitioneducation.com.

Gimme, gimme, gimme a night of song and dance.
Mamma Mia is the ultimate feel-good show.
The stage musical has been wowing audiences since 1999.
It’s due to wow Wellington audiences in 2025.
Get ready to tap your toe to some of ABBA’s most famous songs.

New Zealand’s favourite foodie fest is back.
For the whole month of August, Visa Wellington On a Plate (VWOAP) brings culinary delights to hospitality venues across the city and region.
Expect everything from creative events, delicious pop-up restaurants, and the beloved Burger Wellington.
This year, the festival theme is ‘Food is love’.
It's a tribute to the joy of connecting over kai and the capital’s vibrant, resilient hospitality scene.

Lights, camera, action — the largest film festival in the country is back.
Celebrating 57 years, the Whānau Mārama New Zealand International Film Festival is gearing up for 10 action-packed days in August.
The annual festival presents over 150 feature films, short films, and documentaries.
There’s always a huge and diverse selection of films to choose from.
“These films speak powerfully to the moment we are living in.

Orchestra Wellington is New Zealand’s oldest professional regional orchestra.
Its busy concert series includes music from classical, romantic, and contemporary periods.
You’ll also see it regularly performing with the Orpheus Choir, Royal New Zealand Ballet, and New Zealand Opera.
The programme includes masterpieces that symbolise the artist’s struggle and resilience under repression and political control.
Coupled with works from other composers, the concerts feature local and international soloists.

Inside Circa Theatre’s waterfront venue, you’ll find two performance spaces.
Both offer a smorgasbord of professional theatre throughout the year.
Playwrights from international heavy hitters to brilliant Kiwi voices are represented.
It also includes programming from comedies and cabarets to contemporary dance and pantomime.
Called ‘Velarium’, it undulates in the wind mirroring the water in the harbour.

The Royal New Zealand Ballet (RNZB) pushes boundaries with its 2025 programme.
Diverse and captivating works reflect the vision and influence of artistic director Ty King-Wall.

Celebrate old friends and new flavours as Lola Rouge and Taste of Home unite to celebrate the art of hand-pulled noodles and innovative Asian fusion cuisine. This unique collaboration brings together longtime friends and culinary innovators, whose journey began in the warmth of shared kitchens. Lola Rouge Executive Chef Jason Ng and Taste of Home Chef Tina Hu worked together years ago. Now they find themselves managing and owning restaurants within 100m of each other and were inspired to work together again to create dishes from their childhood and meals they love.
Prepare for a bold and flavourful four-course journey through Asia that celebrates taste, tradition, and technique. The curated menu promises to pack a punch, blending the best of both restaurants with a mix of reimagined classics and soulful, homely flavours, and finishing with a shared dessert tasting platter. From start to finish, Stretch & Slurp promises a feast that is bold, comforting, and best enjoyed in the company of great friends and loved ones!

Enter the magical realm of The Enchanted Ale Quarter, a fairytale-inspired pop-up tavern where whimsy, wonder and craft beer collide.

Step into a storybook setting, with twinkling lights, woodland decor, and forest-fantasy touches around every corner. Feast on gnome and fairy-themed comfort food like the solstice salad, loaded forest fries, sirens & ships fish & chips, and a decadent dark forest brownie, all paired with enchanted brews and mythical tipples.

Cosy, curious, and otherworldly, The Enchanted Ale Quarter brings a little magic to Wellington’s winter nights. Dust off your wings and join us for a pint, some sustenance or a potion, no quest required.

Challenge your taste buds — and your senses — as you experience Dragonfly's expertly crafted mini cocktails and treat size desserts while blindfolded. As your sense of sight fades, your taste, smell, and imagination take centre stage. Can you guess the hidden ingredients behind each delicious bite and sip? Whether you're a food and beverage connoisseur or just curious about new tastes, this immersive experience promises to be full of surprises and delicious discoveries. Will you uncover the secrets behind each sweet treat? The person who guesses the most correct ingredients will receive an $80 Dragonfly voucher and bragging rights as the ultimate flavour detective.

Love Wainuiomata is proud to bring you another energising Wainui Connections Breakfast.
Start your morning right by connecting with like-minded local professionals, business owners, and community leaders. Be inspired by our special guest speakers (to be announced soon!) and enjoy a hearty breakfast
This is your opportunity to:
Share your experience and knowledge
Spark new connections
Strengthen the professional and business fabric of Wainuiomata
Register here: https://forms.gle/F2BoYfkokoD3C9f38
We’re incredibly grateful to all our generous Wainui Connections Breakfast sponsors for making the free kai possible. This session is proudly supported by Hills Wainuiomata and Chubb Life.
Monday, 18th August
7.00AM – 8:00 AM (Doors open 6.30am)
Wainuiomata Community Hub, 1A Queen Street

The Next Gen Cook Off returns for its fifth year, and things are heating up at Everybody Eats.
Every Monday in August, four of Wellington’s freshest young chefs will go head-to-head in a high-energy kitchen takeover, serving up epic three-course dinners using rescued food.

Each chef will be given the same protein, generously provided by Meat Direct, but everything else is a surprise—ingredients are revealed that morning, based on what’s come in. Menus are created on the spot, and dishes are served to a buzzing, hungry crowd. It’s fast-paced, creative chaos with serious culinary skills on display. Guests get a front-row seat to the action, while supporting a truly game-changing enterprise.

4 August — Jessie Gibberd, Loretta
Originally from rural Waikato, Jessie Gibberd made the move to Wellington to study, but it was the buzz of hospitality that captured her heart. Swapping textbooks for tongs, she left her degree behind to dive headfirst into the kitchen. Now a chef de partie at Loretta, Jessie brings a grounded, fresh perspective to one of the city’s most beloved eateries.

11 August — Felipe Molina, El Matador
Hailing from Chile, Felipe Molina is a professional chef with over 15 years of experience in kitchens around the world. Having worked in several countries and world-class restaurants, Felipe brings a global sensibility to his craft. With a passion for seafood, meats, and bold, expressive flavours, his cooking is shaped by travel and tradition, blending international influence with creativity on every plate.

18 August — Zane Gupwell, Graze
Zane Gupwell began his hospitality journey at just 15, washing dishes at a local café in Mount Eden. From there, he headed to Queenstown, learning from a wide range of chefs and kitchen styles before challenging himself with a move to Wellington. Since then, he’s worked at some of the city’s top restaurants and now brings his thoughtful, evolving style to Graze Wine Bar.

25 August — Lulu Temmuyin, Mr Go’s
Lulu Temmuyin is a chef who loves pushing boundaries, even when they’re unexpected. Lactose intolerant but obsessed with cheese, and not a fan of lamb but winner of a lamb cooking competition, Lulu is all about surprises. At Mr Go’s, she brings bold, sustainable flavour to the forefront, blending personality with punch in every dish.

Everybody Eats runs on a pay-what-you-can model, transforming food waste into gourmet meals and bringing the community together over good kai. The Next Gen Cook Off celebrates and champions this mission, proving that rescued food can be next-level delicious.

The Next Gen Cook Off is proudly supported by The Gas Hub.

Uike Kātoanga’i ‘o e lea faka-Tonga – Tonga Language Week
Celebrate: 17 - 23 August 2025
You are invited to join the formal flag raising ceremony, at the Performing Arts Centre inside Pātaka Art + Museum.
There will be morning tea and refreshments following the ceremony.

Uike Kātoanga’i ‘o e lea faka-Tonga – Tonga Language Week Celebrate: 17 - 23 August 2025 You are invited to join the formal flag raising ceremony, at the Peace Memorial in Te Rauparaha Park.
This event is weather dependant and will be moved to the performing arts space at Pātaka if raining.
The flag raising ceremony will also be morning tea and refreshments at Pātaka after the ceremony.
Find out more about the Pacific Language Weeks here: https://poriruacity.govt.nz/your-council/pacific-culture-in-porirua-city/pacific-language-weeks/

This registration is for the two-day in-person workshop on 18th August and 19th August 2025 in Wellington at the James Cook Hotel Grand Chancellor.
The in-person workshop will run from 9.00am - 3.30pm both days.
You must also attend a 3rd day online on 4 September OR 5 September (select one date for 3rd day session) as part of this PLD.
Catering for the in-person workshops will be provided, but this PLD does not include transport costs or accommodation.
When registering, you will need to select from one of our tailored learning options, so we can best cater our content to your role.

If you have tamariki aged 0-6, you’re invited to your local centre during Playcentre Open Week to experience early childhood education with a difference.

Come along for a free visit and support your tamariki to learn through play, while you meet other whānau in your community. From sand and water play, arts and music, to outdoor and messy play, there will be a range of resources and experiences on offer.

With over 400 centres across Aotearoa there is one near you. You get three free visits before enrolling, so why not try a few centres in your community to see what suits you best?

Make a booking at johnsonville@Playcentre.org.nz or 04 478 3904 / 027 880 2425 (phone attended during session hours)

Come along to our weekly play space for Under 5's!
We have an indoor play space equipped with toys and activities and our outdoor facility includes a playground, picnic area, water play area, sandpit and space to run around freely and play!
- Messy play and sensory play activities.
- Music and movement.
More details and enrolments available on our website.

The boil-up is a dish of love, traditionally made in big pots for whānau and friends. It brings people together. Te Papa wanted to capture the essence of this traditional Māori kai and give it a gourmet twist.

Traditional boil-up pork roulade, with Pagro lettuce and tomato, puha mousseline, and horopito aioli in a toasted Brezelmania watercress milk bun, with hand-cut kūmara fries, mānuka honey aioli, a shot of bone broth, and a heart-shaped raspberry framboise dessert.

Join us at the Te Papa Cafe on Level 1, walk-ins welcome. Reserve your spot by booking now.

Please note we aren’t able to accommodate dietary requirements.

Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative.
We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.

Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative.
We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.

Neuroendocrine Cancer NZ is pleased to announce our special annual event will be held in Wellington this year. It's a day designed specifically for people living with Neuroendocrine Cancer (NETs), as well as their whānau, friends, and support networks.
This free, full-day event brings together leading medical experts, wellbeing professionals, and the wider NET community for a meaningful day of learning, connection, and support.
For more information and to register, visit our website: https://www.neuroendocrinecancer.org.nz/net-education-day

Sniff, scratch and burrow at Ngā Turua Kiwi, Kiwi Burrows.
- Climb the towering tree to the top of the forest canopy, then slide all the way down to the forest floor.
PlayHQ is Nōku te Ao Capital E’s public indoor play space for tamariki aged 0-5.
Ngā Tūrua Kiwi will be our final PlayHQ activation at Queens Wharf, before we move to Te Matapihi ki te Ao Nui, the new Central Library.
Nōku te Ao Capital E is located at 4 Queens Wharf, Wellington.

Playcentres across the Wellington region invite whānau with tamariki from birth to school age to come along for a free visit during Playcentre Open Week, which runs from 18-22 August.
Playcentre is a place for you and your tamariki to play, learn and grow together – to strengthen your bond and to make connections with other whānau in your community.
From sand and water play, arts and music, to outdoor and messy play, there will be a range of resources and learning experiences on offer for your tamariki.
Playcentres will be open from 9.30am-11.30am for whānau to visit.
Book your free visit today at www.playcentre.org.nz.

Ready to take a creative break just for YOU?
Join artist Emy from Eclo Art for a beautiful 10-week journey where self-love, mindfulness, and clay art come together in a deeply nourishing experience.

The root of our humanity lies with The Mother's. To support thriving life we are offering A Mother's Space as care and resourcing for ALL Mother's to gather.
Kate Williams and Lily Tanner are Innate Traditions Postpartum Care providers.
We are so honoured to share our offering!
This coming Monday 18th Aug we are in Featherston at the Kiwi Hall.
A Mother’s circle happens every fortnight on a Monday (2nd & 4th of every week). It is for ALL postpartum mothers, no matter the age of your children. You could be freshly postpartum or have older children and felt you are still needing repair, perhaps your postpartum time was not how you wanted or expected? OR you are feeling the disconnect of what it feels like to Mother in these times we are living in.
Whatever it is for you.....This is a S.P.A.C.E where you can show up just as you are. To be SEEN, HEARD, NOURISHED & SUPPORTED. Join in with the village wisdom of the Mothers.
These regular sessions are where we tend to:
Nervous system regulation / breath
Self care
Sharing & community building
Postpartum wisdom & support
Repair
Special guest speakers
Babies, of course, are welcome!
This yummy ‘retreat’ like session tours the Wairarapa- Featherston, Carterton, Masterton and back around again.
This week we are in Masterton at the Hōkai Tahi building 21 Worksop Road. 10 am start.
All welcome! Bookings are recommended but not essential, you can just drop in. $20 cash at the door.
Book here: https://classes.as.me/?appointmentType=77697735

‘Animals first entered the imagination as messengers and promises,’ John Berger.
Messengers explores the enduring gaze shared between humans and other animals. The exhibition title is inspired by a line from John Berger’s seminal 1977 essay ‘Why Look at Animals?’ Berger argued that the relationship between humans and animals – ‘our unspeaking companionship’ – has been transformed by capitalism.
Messengers brings together historical and contemporary ways of looking at animals in photography and art. It features archival photographs from the National Library and Alexander Turnbull Collections, first taken by newspaper photographers in the mid twentieth century. The images capture everything from the polar bears once housed in Wellington Zoo, to an elderly gentleman standing amongst the life size concrete animal sculptures in his garden. These images are at once tender and loving, sentimental and silly, kind and indifferent.
Messengers places these archival photographs in proximity and conversation with contemporary sculpture and moving image works by four Aotearoa-based artists: Denise Batchelor, Brit Bunkley, Jane Dodd and John Ward Knox. From eerie AI and computer-generated animals to the hypnotic stare of a real live Ruru; from carved wooden godwits you can hold in your hand to ‘hominoid’ brooches, each artist’s work speaks to the ‘unspeaking companionship’ between humanity and other animals.
IMAGE Brit Bunkley, still from Transit, single channel video, 2025

Eat Your Art Out brings a creative twist to high tea, inspired by the bold and brilliant works of Toi Art.
Enjoy a menu of classic treats with an artistic edge: from the Sweet William’s Dish, Golden Ratio Scone, Madeleine Moment, and the Mint to Be mousse.
Alcoholic beverages are available for purchase, and dietary options are available on request.
Every purchase helps to support Aotearoa New Zealand’s national museum.
------ Set Menu (Includes one of each item per person) Cheery Cherry Curator A silky milk chocolate crémeux layered with vibrant cherry glaze and topped with a dark chocolate disc creates a perfectly balanced blend of tart and sweet Mint to Be Cool mint and sweet strawberry mousse gently resting on a white chocolate base, combining vibrant flavours that are meant to be together Madeleine Moment A citrus-infused madeleine paired with silky sambuca namelaka, vibrant green apple gel, and an elegant chocolate garnish delivers golden flavours with a playful twist Sweet William’s Dish Mānuka honey ganache nestled in a crisp vanilla tart shell, topped with a chocolate ‘The Dish’ by William De Morgan.

Interislander has been a long-time supporter of Visa Wellington on a Plate, the famous hospitality event that lights up the Wellington region each August.

The Love Ferry
Featuring a Poneke Red brioche bun, with a beef & pork patty seasoned with a mix of smoked paprika, garlic, and a touch of cayenne pepper. Melted Kapiti brie cheese with caramelised onions, roasted red peppers, rocket and truffle aioli. Topped with crispy Harrington’s bacon and pickled jalepenos for those who like a little heat. Served with a side of crispy fries sprinkled with smoked paprika and sea salt at $20. For the perfect pairing, we offer a Garage Project Beer match for $12.

Pop-up Burger at Wellington Railway Station
We've set up a pop-up burger truck outside the Wellington Railway Station. This will allow the public to indulge in our burger and fries without needing to sail on the Interislander. Its also available to passengers when travelling the Cook Strait on the Ferry.

This 60 minute session is an energising and refreshing experience to carry you through the day and reduce the build up of work-related stress and fatigue.
Suitable for everyone.
The Monday's Lunchtime class focuses more on the problem with the back and neck care.
Wednesdays: 12.15 - 1.15pm Fridays: 12.15 - 1.15pm Drop in :$18 or 10 class concession card for $140

Join editor and poet Nick Ascroft as he introduces a crackling selection of New Zealand poets from his edition of the annual online anthology Ōrongohau | Best New Zealand Poems.
James Brown, Robin Peace, Simon Sweetman, Stacey Teague, Philomena Johnson, Kiri Piahana-Wong, Zephyr Zhang, and others will read their work, and poems by the late Fleur Adcock, Vincent O’Sullivan, and Paula Harris will also be celebrated in this warm-up to Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day.
Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre, Meow and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day and supported by the Letteri Family.

Join editor and poet Nick Ascroft as he introduces a crackling selection of New Zealand poets from his edition of the annual online anthology Ōrongohau | Best New Zealand Poems.
James Brown, Robin Peace, Simon Sweetman, Stacey Teague, Philomena Johnson, Kiri Piahana-Wong, Zephyr Zang, and others will read their work, and poems by the late Fleur Adcock, Vincent O'Sullivan, and Paula Harris will also be celebrated in this warm-up to Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day.
Writers on Mondays is presented by the International Institute of Modern Letters and Te Papa Tongarewa.
The 2025 series will run from 12.15—1.15 pm each Monday from 7 July to 29 September at Te Papa Tongarewa and Circa Theatre, with two special evening sessions at Meow.
Admission is free and all are welcome.

Join us and our doggy guests from Canine Friends Pet Therapy for Read to Kurī at the library. You can book a 15-minute session to sit with one of our friendly dogs and read your favourite book, or one you've found at the library.
Read to Kurī aims to help children improve their literacy, self-confidence, and self-esteem in a relaxed, non-judgemental environment. This programme is perfect for tamariki aged 5+ who would like to practice their reading skills while making a new canine friend at the library.
To book your session, please call the library on 04 477 6151, or email johnsonville.library@wcc.govt.nz with your preferred date and time.
Bookings are for 15 minutes only. After you have booked, library staff will be in contact informing you what time to arrive for your session.

A fun night full of vibes and nostalgia!

Come watch Ratatouille (2007) to support our 3rd year Major Project "Bad Egg", you would be helping towards costs for transporting our gear and crew, amazing cast, beautiful locations and feeding our talents and creatives!

Movie starts at 5.30pm so come anytime before, the earlier the better seats!

Our language classes are delivered by experienced Chinese language teachers with an emphasis on practical and enjoyable learning.
We offer five classes for Novice, Beginners, Elementary, Pre-intermediate, and Intermediate levels. All classes run for 10 weeks small class sizes ranging from approximately 3 to 10 people. These classes are suitable for learners 14 years older and are held at the VUW Pipitea Campus.
Term 3 classes begin on 18 August 2025 and registration closes on 20 July 2025.
For more information on our classes go to our language courses page. https://www.wgtn.ac.nz/ci/courses-and-tests/courses

Pro Tools Update + Audio Community Networking Night
In Partnership with Atomise, Join Dan Lovell and Drew Parsons from Avid for an evening filled with exciting updates on the latest Pro Tools software. Connect with fellow audio experts, share tips and tricks, and expand your network in the industry. Whether you're a seasoned pro or just starting out, this event is perfect for anyone passionate about audio production. Don't miss this opportunity to learn, collaborate, and have a great time with like-minded individuals. See you there!

Whether you're a seasoned pro or just starting out, this event is perfect for anyone passionate about audio production. Don't miss this opportunity to learn, collaborate, and have a great time with like-minded individuals. See you there!

Connect with other like minded people that have a love of dance.
Brazilian Zouk was developed in Rio de Janeiro in the mid 90s, and is now becoming more and more popular
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DfhRHnEAbak
..............
This is stunning to watch and even more fun to dance! It is based on the original Lambada dance but adapted to more modern music with a slow-quick-quick beat. It can be danced to a wide variety of music including R&B, Rock and Pop.
In this block of 5 classes you will discover the fundamental techniques, movements and sequences of Brazilian Zouk to get you up and running on the dance floor.
This includes:
Week 1: Passo basico
Week 2: Viradinha
Week 3: Io-Io
Week 4: Bonus
Week 5: Combination
They are designed so you can start this block as a complete newbie, or you can continue on as an existing student from the last block.
There are 4 blocks of classes (A, B, C, D) in the complete Fundamentals course. Once these are done, you can progress to the Improvers classes.
Prices and payment:
- Prepaid 5 week term cost is $90 waged or $75 for unwaged/students.
- Ad hoc cost is $20 waged or $18 unwaged/students
Online payments can be made to Adam Polaczuk
Acct: 03-0531-0559348-25
Details: Your name and ZoukFunB

Let's master the foundation steps and basic turn patters of Cuban Salsa.

Let’s keep dancing and growing together – we can’t wait to see you in class
If you are not sure if this level is for you drop us an email and come and try: lily@salsatherapy.co.nz

The yoga exercises from Yoga in Daily Life Level 1 and 2 are designed for beginners and those who want to build a firm foundation to their existing practice.
Includes: yoga exercises to increase flexibility and strength of muscles and improve the function of internal organs; yogic breathing to reduce stress and anxiety; traditional pranayama, relaxation and meditation techniques.

Doctors For Nutrition and MTM Charity invite you to an evening of inspiration, education, and connection at our next ‘Dine with a Doc’ dinner.
Join us for a presentation on ‘The Power of Plant-Based Nutrition and Lifestyle Interventions for Preventing Chronic Disease’—an event designed to empower everyone from healthcare professionals to health-conscious community members.
You will also be the first to hear about the new MTM charity, and about their mission.
Through easy-to-understand explanations of key concepts - such as endothelial dysfunction, intramyocellular lipid accumulation, and calorie density - you’ll discover how WFPB eating can dramatically improve health outcomes and transform lives.
After the presentation, join us for a panel discussion and a Q&A session with Dr Haitjema and Dr Luke Wilson.

Lebanese-Palestinian American, born in Oakland California, Sammy Obeid double majored in Business and Mathematics at UC Berkeley and then turned down a job at Google to be a comedian. Now the host of 100 Humans on Netflix, he’s also appeared on NBC's Last Comic Standing and America's Got Talent, as well as TBS’s Conan, and is best known for his world record of performing comedy 1,001 nights in a row, a story featured in both Time Magazine and The New York Times.

Holy Knit Batman!
It’s the Southern Cross Yarning Circle!
Now you can wile away the evening hours, knitting and nattering or flip the script and give Grandma a cardie next Christmas.
Just bring down some wool and needles, or your preferred stitchcraft.
Crocheters and other stitchers all welcome.

Welcome to TERM 4
This term we will focus on social dancing and strengthen your foundations with cool combos and partner connection drills. Perfect for steady progress.
Choose the package that suits you best:
Dame Una – 1 lesson per week: $157
Dame Dos – 2 lessons per week: $252 (e.g Salsa + Bachata)

Across six immersive sessions (the first being a practica), we'll Continue to learn the fundamentals of Traditional Samba de Gafieira.
We will continue to deepen your knowledge, continuing on learning the concepts started in the first block of Samba de Gafieira classes.
Week 1: Practice/party/catch up
Week 2: Sacada + Sacada Invertido
Week 3: Romario
Week 4: Pica Pau
Week 5: Esse + Esse saida
Week 6: Facao + Facinha
Samba de gafieira is the partnered version of Brazil’s world-renowned, samba no pe. Samba de Gafieira is danced to the Brazilian samba musical rhythms and must be distinguished from the ballroom Samba, danced in International Latin and American Rhythm ballroom dance styles.
Check out this demo : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JMGlfr3zA5w
It appeared in the 1940s and it gets its name from the Gafieira – popular urban nightclubs of Rio de Janeiro at that time. The dance derived from the Maxixe and followed the arrival of the Choro (another samba musical style). It left most of the Maxixe’s Polka elements behind but maintained the entwined leg movements of the Argentine Tango, although adopting a more relaxed posture than the latter. Many see this form of Samba as a combination of Waltz and Tango.

Speakers: Ilse Breitwieser, Research Associate – Botanist; Rob Smissen, Senior Researcher – Botanist. Allan Herbarium, Manaaki Whenua – Landcare Research, Lincoln.
Call them billy-buttons, drumstick flowers, billy balls, sun balls (in Australia) or woollyheads and puatea in New Zealand, or with their scientific name Craspedia (Gnaphalieae, Compositae/Asteraceae), these everlasting daisies are conspicuous members of many plant communities in New Zealand and Australia but remain an outstanding taxonomic challenge.
In 1961, based on a small number of available herbarium specimens, HH Allan’s Flora of New Zealand volume 1 recorded just 6 species in New Zealand. However, the 1992 and 1993 checklists of Tony Druce, who made extensive field observations and collected numerous herbarium specimens, distinguished more than 45 undescribed entities that might warrant taxonomic recognition.
Morphological variation in New Zealand Craspedia is complex, making the definition and circumscription of species problematic. At least in part, this difficulty is the legacy of an extremely rapid and recent diversification of the genus in New Zealand—a scenario that produces challenges for genetic as well as morphological approaches to delimiting species.

Come and join us for Improvers Zouk Block D (5 weeks).
We have some great new content for you this year and will be building on foundational movements.
The complete Improvers course consists of 6 different Blocks (A-F).
Each block focuses on a different aspect and technique of Brazilian Zouk and so they can be completed independently of each other.
Our recommendation is to complete all 6 Blocks before progressing onto the Brazilian Zouk Deep Dive classes.
In Improvers Block D you will get an Introduction to Tilted turns as well as some exercises on Floor craft and the Social Dance experience.

Dust off the denim, dig out the flip phones and get ready to rewind time. Two Grey is bringing back Arizona Bar & Grill for a limited-time pop-up.

Welcome to The Arizona Flashback, a throwback to the late '90s and early 2000s that revives the flavours, energy and atmosphere of the iconic Arizona Bar & Grill. Known as a go-to spot for after-work drinks, late-night bites, birthday celebrations and casual catch-ups, Arizona was a place where people came together over great food and good times.

Now, its beloved Southwestern-style dishes and all-day menu return — not just as a delicious nod to the past, but as a celebration of shared moments, laughter and connection.

Immerse yourself in the full Y2K dining experience, complete with retro beats, neon lights and the return of Arizona’s famous Spin the Wheel game for a dash of playful nostalgia.

Raw Meat Monday is back for 2025!
Wellington's longest-running open mic comedy night.

If you’re trying comedy for the first time, Raw Meat is the safest place to start.

Get ready to master the art of making Wellington's iconic cheese scones at Pravda Café. Widely regarded as the home of the city's best cheese scones, Pravda's creations are so beloved, they often sell out before you can blink. Now, you can learn the secrets behind their mouthwatering scones firsthand.

In this hands-on workshop, you’ll be guided through mixing and preparing your own batch of Pravda’s famous cheese scones. Once your dough is ready, you'll hand them off to be baked to crispy flaky perfection. While they cook, relax with a cup of tea or coffee, and once your scones are ready, you’ll enjoy the fruits of your labour fresh from the oven.

The best part? You’ll get to take home the coveted recipe, allowing you to recreate these legendary scones in your own kitchen whenever you want. This is a perfect opportunity to learn a piece of Wellington’s culinary history and enjoy a deliciously rewarding experience.

“Holy Onion”. For the entire month, Cicio Cacio Osteria is getting brave and bold, celebrating the magic of vegetables in all their glory, especially the santa cipolla (aka the holy onion). 
Vegetables bring colour, life and joy. In Italy, they mark the rhythm of the seasons, stir up cherished memories and signal the excitement of fresh beginnings. Come along and experience vibrant flavours with playful snacks, fun street food, freshly baked breads, handmade pasta and a brand new range of dishes that celebrate the beauty, bounty and simplicity of Italian cuisine.

Join fragrance aficionado Benny Castles for an immersive journey into the WORLD of love, told through the art of scent. In this exclusive olfactive experience, indulge in small bites and sip on a glass (or three!) of something delightful, setting the perfect mood for exploring the emotional power of fragrance.

Over the course of the evening, you’ll sample up to twelve unique fragrances, each one tied to a captivating love story that inspired its creation. Learn the intimate tales behind these scents and discover how they evoke the passions and emotions that shape our experiences of love. Whether you're a fragrance enthusiast or a newcomer, this sensory journey is sure to arouse your olfactory senses and deepen your appreciation for the art of perfume.

𝗡𝗭 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗧𝗼𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗿𝗼𝘄 𝗖𝗵𝗮𝗽𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗶𝘁
The Educate Plus NZ Chapter is thrilled to invite you to our 2025 Summit taking place on Tuesday 19 & Wednesday 20 August at Victoria University of Wellington for the 𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗧𝗼𝗺𝗼𝗿𝗿𝗼𝘄 𝗖𝗵𝗮𝗽𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗦𝘂𝗺𝗺𝗶𝘁. This professional development opportunity will bring together Advancement Practitioners from across New Zealand, in Tertiary Institutions and Schools, all dedicated to shaping the future together.
The Summit, with sessions in Admissions, Alumni & Community Relations, Fundraising, Marketing & Communications, Leadership and People & Culture, will be more than just a learning experience—it will also be an opportunity to connect, collaborate, and share insights with professionals who, like you, are passionate about building a better tomorrow.
Through these engaging sessions, meaningful conversations, and shared ideas, you’ll gain the tools and inspiration to create the future you envision, supported by the collective wisdom and energy of the New Zealand Chapter community.
Don’t miss this opportunity … Let’s Make Tomorrow —together.
